perturbation.original_text: 1.1 "SOFTWARE USER" means a named user of the Corio Services worldwide to whom a user identification number and password has been assigned, which permits that user to access and use the Software on a designated Corio Server. The identification number and password used by a Software User is reusable and reassignable and may be used and transferred by Corio, in accordance with the licenses granted below, between Customers as one Customer discontinues the Corio Services and another Customer subscribes.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.1 "SOFTWARE USER" means any individual worldwide accessing the Corio Services, regardless of assigned credentials, to utilize the Software on a Corio Server. The system user is permanently tied to the initial Customer account and cannot be reassigned or transferred under any circumstances.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition of "SOFTWARE USER" allowed for reassignment of user credentials between Customers. The modified definition explicitly prohibits this reassignment, creating an internal contradiction. This creates uncertainty around the portability of user licenses between subscribing customers. The in-text contradiction is made within the same section 1.1, where the definition initially allows and later forbids the reassignment of the user.
perturbation.contradicted_text: 1.1 "SOFTWARE USER" means any individual worldwide accessing the Corio Services, regardless of assigned credentials, to utilize the Software on a Corio Server. The system user is permanently tied to the initial Customer account and cannot be reassigned or transferred under any circumstances.

perturbation.original_text: 1.6 "CUSTOMER(S)" means one or more customers of the Corio Services having its principal executive offices in the Territory who obtains a sublicense from Corio to use the Software or MarketSite.net Service, in the Corio Market Segment.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.6 "CUSTOMER(S)" means any entity utilizing the Corio Services, irrespective of their location or market segment, that accesses the Software or MarketSite.net Service. This includes end-users, affiliates, or any party granted access through Corio.
perturbation.explanation: The initial definition restricted "CUSTOMER(S)" to those within the Territory (North America) and within the Corio Market Segment (annual sales less than $1B). The modified version broadens this to any entity using the service, regardless of location or revenue, creating an internal contradiction. This change also affects Section 2.10, regarding expansion of the geographical scope of the licenses. It introduces ambiguity over whether the restrictions in the rest of the contract now apply to this broader definition of 'Customer'.
perturbation.contradicted_text: 2.10 Expansion of Geographical Scope. The parties agree Corio may seek permission to expand the scope of the licenses granted under this Section 2 worldwide, at no additional cost to Corio, and maintaining the revenue sharing provisions contained herein, and Commerce One shall not unreasonably withhold its permission to expand all such licenses worldwide at no additional cost to Corio. If and when localized versions of the Software become available, these versions shall be made available under the maintenance and support provisions of this Agreement.

perturbation.original_text: 3.1 Delivery and Acceptance. Commerce One shall issue to Corio, via electronic means of delivery, as soon as practicable, one (1) machine-readable copy of the Software, along with one (1) copy of the on-line Documentation. Commerce One will provide Corio with one written copy of the Documentation at no cost, and any additional written copies at Commerce One's standard charges. Corio acknowledges that no copy of the source code of the Software will be provided to 4 5 Corio. Within thirty (30) days of delivery of the Software, but in no event later than December 1, 1999, Corio shall test the Software for conformance with the Documentation ("Acceptance Test"). If the Software performs in substantial accordance with the Documentation, then Corio shall notify Commerce One in writing of its acceptance of the Software. In the event Corio finds material errors or defects with the Software, Corio shall notify Commerce One in writing of such errors or defects and provide adequate detail to facilitate Commerce One replicating the error or defect. Upon receipt of written notice, Commerce One shall have fifteen (15) days to correct the defect, reinstall the Software at the Corio site and re-perform the Acceptance Test. If Corio does not accept the Software after the second Acceptance Test, a third Acceptance Test will be performed. Notwithstanding the foregoing, all Acceptance Testing shall be complete by December 30, 1999, and Corio shall notify Commerce One in writing of it's acceptance or rejection of the Software no later than December 31, 1999. If after the third Acceptance Test Corio does not accept the Software, Corio may, at its sole option, elect to (i) repeat the Acceptance Test or (ii) terminate the Agreement and receive a refund of any fees paid to Commerce One as of such date. Both parties acknowledge that any professional services provided to Corio subsequent to the installation and acceptance of the Software are non-essential for the purpose of the acceptance of the Software.
perturbation.changed_text: 3.1 Delivery and Acceptance. Commerce One shall provide Corio with continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD) access to the Software, along with real time documentation through a shared cloud respository. Commerce One will provide Corio with no physical or written copies of the Documentation at no cost. Corio acknowledges that no copy of the source code of the Software will be provided to Corio. Within thirty (30) days of the initial access to the Software, but in no event later than December 1, 1999, Corio shall provide feedback on user stories and functionality with the provided CI/CD documentation ("Acceptance Test"). If the Software performs in substantial accordance with the Documentation, then Corio shall notify Commerce One of its approval of user stories and the CI/CD functionality. In the event Corio finds material errors or defects with the Software user stories or CI/CD Documentation, Corio shall notify Commerce One of such errors or defects and provide adequate detail to facilitate Commerce One replicating the error or defect. Upon receipt of notice, Commerce One shall have ninety (90) days to correct the user stories, CI/CD pipeline and re-perform the Acceptance Test. If Corio does not accept the user stories and CI/CD process after the second Acceptance Test, a third Acceptance Test will be performed. Notwithstanding the foregoing, all Acceptance Testing shall be complete by December 30, 1999, and Corio shall notify Commerce One of it's acceptance or rejection of the Software, user stories and the CI/CD pipeline no later than December 31, 1999. If after the third Acceptance Test Corio does not accept the Software, Corio may, at its sole option, elect to (i) repeat the Acceptance Test or (ii) terminate the Agreement and receive a refund of any fees paid to Commerce One as of such date. Both parties acknowledge that any professional services provided to Corio subsequent to the installation and acceptance of the Software are non-essential for the purpose of the acceptance of the Software.
perturbation.explanation: The modification changes the 'Delivery and Acceptance' clause from delivering a 'machine-readable copy of the Software' to 'CI/CD access' and shifting the focus from testing software conformance to reviewing "user stories and CI/CD functionality". This introduces the in-text contradiction because the contract is written expecting software to be delivered at once for testing according to the Documentation. Now Acceptance testing is based on 'user stories' and 'CI/CD functionality' instead. The text refers to the 'Software performs in substantial accordance with the Documentation' however the acceptance process is centered around User Stories.
perturbation.contradicted_text: 3.1 Delivery and Acceptance. Commerce One shall provide Corio with continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD) access to the Software, along with real time documentation through a shared cloud respository. Commerce One will provide Corio with no physical or written copies of the Documentation at no cost. Corio acknowledges that no copy of the source code of the Software will be provided to Corio. Within thirty (30) days of the initial access to the Software, but in no event later than December 1, 1999, Corio shall provide feedback on user stories and functionality with the provided CI/CD documentation ("Acceptance Test"). If the Software performs in substantial accordance with the Documentation, then Corio shall notify Commerce One of its approval of user stories and the CI/CD functionality. In the event Corio finds material errors or defects with the Software user stories or CI/CD Documentation, Corio shall notify Commerce One of such errors or defects and provide adequate detail to facilitate Commerce One replicating the error or defect. Upon receipt of notice, Commerce One shall have ninety (90) days to correct the user stories, CI/CD pipeline and re-perform the Acceptance Test. If Corio does not accept the user stories and CI/CD process after the second Acceptance Test, a third Acceptance Test will be performed. Notwithstanding the foregoing, all Acceptance Testing shall be complete by December 30, 1999, and Corio shall notify Commerce One of it's acceptance or rejection of the Software, user stories and the CI/CD pipeline no later than December 31, 1999. If after the third Acceptance Test Corio does not accept the Software, Corio may, at its sole option, elect to (i) repeat the Acceptance Test or (ii) terminate the Agreement and receive a refund of any fees paid to Commerce One as of such date. Both parties acknowledge that any professional services provided to Corio subsequent to the installation and acceptance of the Software are non-essential for the purpose of the acceptance of the Software.
